page.title: 02Local history: Cordon Hill
page.content: Corndon is a conical hill formed by an intrusion of dolerite into the ordovician shales and rising to a height of{513m}above sea level. There are 6 round cairns on the hill , (at SO30449666; SO306096; SO30909676 ; SO30949680; SO30869632; and SO30539608 ) with two further examples on the lower slopes at ( SO29999670 & SO30409753 ). These cairns are probably of Bronze Age date. Although several of them appear to have opened at some time , there are no records of burials found nor any grave goods. To the North of Corndon and on its lowest slopes a{stone circle}, the Whetstones , stood all traces were finally removed by gun powder in 1860.
